body: ON an August night eight years ago, my taxi slowed on Broadway at West 79th Street. A doorman in gold buttons swept open a gate, and we rolled into the courtyard of the Apthorp, a Renaissance-style building where a childhood friend lived. It became my first home in New York. For three weeks, I crashed in an elegant room whose walls smelled of musky
title: There's No Place Like Home. But There's . . . No Place.

body: CONTEMPORARY art in New York is a half-empty, half-full situation. Depending on whom you listen to, it's either terminally confused and uncentered, or healthily, refreshingly diverse. (Personally, I think confusion is healthy, so I win either way.) Almost anyone would agree, though, that the art world is itself fragmented. There's a centralized
title: ART REVIEW; For Hikers Seeking Art, Brooklyn Is a Left Bank

body: Almost a decade ago, a newcomer riding the elevated F train over the Gowanus Canal was told to look out the window. ''That's Red Hook, where the gangsters throw dead bodies,'' said her friend, pointing to the murky water below. ''Even the subway doesn't stop there.'' The subway still does not stop in Red Hook, but the new ''Neighborhood History
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK/GOWANUS; Frommer's It's Not; Guidebook Burnishes a Rugged Image

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, through Dec. 31. Tomorrow from 10 to 11:30 a.m., ''The Christmas Stocking,''
title: SPARE TIMES

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. body: FLATBUSH Yiddish Theater, Klezmer And a Tribute to Israel Mike Burstyn and Lillian Lux will perform classics from the golden age of Yiddish theater next Sunday to kick off the Jewish Gems Series at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts. The second event in the series, on March 4, is ''Klez! Klez! Klez!'' This celebration of klezmer music will
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: THE year is 1008. Now that you've braved the Atlantic Ocean to reach a new continent and fathered the first European child on those shores, what are you going to do? I'm going to Gowanus! That scenario does not quite represent the standard history of the Vikings in North America. But the idea of their heading south to Gowanus Bay in Brooklyn seemed
title: The Big City; After Ocean Trip, Leif's Descendant Says Vikings Were Here

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has recently opened, with the same hours as the museum. Opening tomorrow, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' live, multicolored
title: SPARE TIMES

body: THE work of Eddie Earl Cato (1941-1980) and his son, Nicholas Evans-Cato (who was born in 1973) pays homage to the Gowanus Canal and the once-thriving industrial center around it. Mr. Cato studied at Brooklyn College and later worked there; Mr. Evans-Cato was born in Brooklyn and still lives in the borough. Their work is on exhibit at the Prospect
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK; Cityscapes by Father and Son

body: LOWER MANHATTAN The Ferry Experience: A Commuter's Video Ed Davin has lived on Staten Island since 1966 and has spent 20 years commuting on the Staten Island Ferry. His video, ''The Ferry in Light and Shadow,'' includes 131 black and white photographs illustrating the ferry experience. The 21-minute tape is currently being shown in the Whitehall
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: The lights of Ebbets Field, which gazed down on a golden past of Robinsons and Reeses and Walkers and Furillos, found a home in Downing Stadium when the wrecking ball tore into the home of the Dodgers and stilled the heart of Brooklyn. Now dem lights -- or whatever may be left of them -- are about to go homeless again. Downing Stadium faces
title: Ebbets Lights Dimmed Again; In City Prizing Relics, Link to Dodgers Needs a Home

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Joe McCarthy sees Redcoats everywhere in Brooklyn. In his mind's eye, British troops come surging by the tens of thousands off the war boats massed in the Narrows off Bay Ridge, just as they did on the humid, breezy morning of Aug. 27, 1776. They march in endless formation up Fourth Avenue, past the auto body places and worn bodegas, and pelt the
title: Red Cars, Not Coats, And a Cast Of One; Battle of Brooklyn, Evoked on a Budget

body: Thoughts of hungry striped bass hung in the air, bright as the nearly full moon rising in the afternoon haze over Long Island. Though not a swirl or splash could yet be seen, Rob Maass and John Waidman stood supremely confident, casting bucktails from shore into a quiet backwater. They had lured me here with tales of wild fishing they had stumbled
title: OUTDOORS; Unusual Setting, But Fish Still Bite

body: Glass Goes Silver Heller Gallery, 420 West 14th Street; (212) 414-4014. The 25th annual Glass America exhibition, featuring glass sculptures by more than 40 artists, starts tomorrow and continues through Aug. 19. The works will include blown glass forms by Dante Marioni that are reminiscent of Roman vessels; a sculpture by Mary Shaffer involving
title: CALENDAR; Tours, Shows, Classes

author: Stephen S. Hall is a contributing writer for the magazine. His most recent article was about embryo research.
body: On a wet, blustery April morning, mist blowing sideways across the docks marking the lower end of Union Street on the Brooklyn waterfront, 17-year-old Alice Warren-Gregory races down the steps from her family's third-floor apartment a little after 5:30 a.m. Clutching a calculator and a copy of ''The Great Gatsby,'' she hurries up the block in the
title: The Smart Set

title: COMMUNITY BOARDS; The Brooklyn Meetings, From Sea Gate to Dumbo

body: The Meadowlands is one of the most reviled and ecologically damaged pieces of land in the United States, while it is some of the most valuable and environmentally fragile land in the country. Because of that contradiction, the Meadowlands has become an environmental battleground. That battle is depicted in an art exhibition and film and discussion
title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; Art and the Environment

body: A 12-year-old boy was shot in the chest and critically injured in Brooklyn yesterday as he and two friends played with a gun that they told the police they found in a vacant lot, the authorities said. It was not clear who fired the gun, said Detective Joseph Pentangelo, a police spokesman. The victim, Matthew Marino, was in critical but stable
title: Boy, 12, Shot While Playing With a Gun

body: A truck driver was killed last night when his truck plummeted nearly 40 feet off the Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn and landed on top of a livery cab, the police said. The livery driver walked away from the crash. The trucker, driving a box truck filled with mattresses for S. Persaud Trucking of Queens, was driving north on the elevated expressway
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Man Killed When Truck Falls Off Gowanus

body: THE oil painting of St. Augustine's Church at Sixth Avenue and Sterling Place in Park Slope (shown) was done in 1997 by an artist who walks past the landmark site almost daily. Gregory Frux, 42, is a resident of Park Slope and an architect with a Master of Fine Arts from Brooklyn College. A show of his work from the last five years is at the New
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; In Praise of Urban Landscape

body: If the Gowanus Canal is looking a little sluggish these days, there's a reason. The canal's flushing tunnel, which turned the Gowanus, Brooklyn's legendarily filthy waterway, into a bouillabaisse of frolicking sea creatures when it began drawing cleaner water from New York Harbor into the canal last year, has been out of commission since March 14.
title: Propeller Jam in Tunnel Slows Flow of Water in Gowanus Canal

Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is

body: CONSIDERING the setting for the following interview a big, bustling gun factory in Brooklyn -- what comes next may be hard to believe. But Anthony F. Imperato and his family have never really been all that crazy about guns. ''Guns were just not a part of our lives,'' he said. ''Other than the fact that we sold them.'' These days, the business that
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Selling Guns: A Tradition and a Dilemma

body: To the Editor: There is an opportunity for New York to commit itself to large-scale public works, but the worthy projects are not mostly limited to Manhattan (editorial, March 26). In Brooklyn, communities and local elected officials are close to completing a $2 million master plan for a major new park and recreational area around the Brooklyn
title: A City of Visions, Large and Small

body: FOR a devotee of the ''Godfather'' movies, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a shocking gaffe during this year's State of the City address. It came right after he described his crusades against organized crime at the Fulton Fish Market and the carting industry. ''We've reduced the influence of the Mafia so much,'' Mr. Giuliani boasted, ''now when they
title: The Big City; Hey, Rudy G.: Bring Back The Sopranos

author: John Waldman is the author of ''Heartbeats in the Muck: The History, Sea Life and Environment of New York Harbor,'' published last month by Lyons Press.
body: THERE are standard, packaged ways to meet New York Harbor -- taking the Circle Line tour or the Staten Island Ferry -- and in doing so one can see many of its renowned sights. But to learn the essential character of the harbor, one must see its many uncelebrated spaces, large and small. The New Yorker writer Joseph Mitchell knew this a half century
title: The Harbor Nobody Knows; New York's Reviving Waterfront Teems With Hidden Treasures

body: SWIRLING snow, cars turned to soft lumps on the street, the city as silent as a Vermont woods. I felt an irresistible need to go to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. I bundled up as if I were in the north country and walked a mile to the garden, pleasantly disoriented because familiar landmarks were veiled by the storm. Yet, other perceptions were
title: HUMAN NATURE; Under a Canvas of Snow, a Garden of the Imagination

body: All New York City mayors dream about changing the face of their realm, of erecting a physical legacy. Fiorello La Guardia is remembered for his public housing, the airport that bears his name and the alliance he forged with Robert Moses, the most grandiose builder of all. John V. Lindsay fought for urban renewal. Edward I. Koch is credited with the
title: Master Plans or Pipe Dreams; Giuliani Proposes Monuments; Skeptics See Fantasies

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: MIDTOWN Top Hats, Lots of Legs And White Grand Pianos A turning point in the history of Hollywood is illustrated this month in the film series ''Sing Out! The Hollywood Musical During the 1930's,'' beginning Wednesday at the Donnell Library. The movie musical is said to be the only film genre to emerge after the coming of sound, and many mediocre
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
